Guide to Using the 2007 NECAP Reports
Guide to Using the 2007 NECAP Reports

Purpose of the Workshop
Purpose of the Workshop
page.enlisting:
• Review the different types of NECAP reports • Discuss effective ways to analyze and interpret • Provide schools and districts an opportunity to share how they have analyzed results data • Review the different types of NECAP reports
• Review the different types of NECAP reports
• Discuss effective ways to analyze and interpret

page.title:
FERPA
FERPA
page.normal_text:
The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)
The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)

Access to individual student results is restricted to: o the student o the student’s parents/guardians o authorized school personnel
Access to individual student results is restricted to:
o the student
o the student’s parents/guardians
o authorized school personnel

Superintendents and principals are responsible for maintaining the privacy and security of all student records.
Superintendents and principals are responsible for maintaining the
privacy and security of all student records.

Authorized school personnel shall have access to the records of students to whom they are providing services when such access is required in the performance of their official duties.
Authorized school personnel shall have access to the records of
students to whom they are providing services when such access is
required in the performance of their official duties.

FERPA website: http://www.ed.gov/policy/gen/guid/fpco/ferpa/index.html
FERPA website:
http://www.ed.gov/policy/gen/guid/fpco/ferpa/index.html

page.normal_text:
Three essential questions…
Three essential questions…

• How did we do? • What do the data tell us about parts of our program? • What do the data tell us about parts of our population? • Looking at the different school-level reports (group data) • Looking at the Item Analysis Report (primarily individual student data) • How did we do?

page.title:
What do the data tell us about parts of our population?

parts of our population?
page.normal_text:
Question #3
Question #3

How did the various sub-groups perform relative to:
How did the various sub-groups perform relative to:

a. the district? b. the state? c. the same sub-groups last year? d. what we would have predicted knowing the population?
a. the district?
b. the state?
c. the same sub-groups last year?
d. what we would have predicted knowing the
population?

How do the percentages of students in the various sub-groups compare to the district and state?

sub-groups compare to the district and state?

page.title:
Before You Go Any Further…
Before You Go Any Further…
page.normal_text:
What questions will you answer and for what audiences?
What questions will you answer and for what audiences?
page.enlisting:
• Based on what you know about your school’s programs and students, and how they have changed, what do you expect to see? (For example, how would a specific year’s 5th graders perform relative to 5th graders from previous years?) • What processes will you use to look at your reports? • Will you look at teaching year or testing year reports? • Who should participate in the discussions? • How should you group the participants? • Based on what you know about your school’s programs and students, and how they have changed, what do you expect to see? (For example, how would a specific year’s 5th graders perform relative to 5th graders from previous years?)

page.title:
Small Group Activity
Small Group Activity
page.enlisting:
1. Select at least one of the three essential questions 2. Select your target audience 3. Begin to answer the question by examining your data 4. Note key findings or conclusions 5. Begin to discuss strategies for improvement 6. Be prepared to share your findings with the large group 1. Select at least one of the three essential questions
1. Select at least one of the three essential questions
2. Select your target audience
2. Select your target audience
3. Begin to answer the question by examining your data
3. Begin to answer the question by examining your data
4. Note key findings or conclusions
4. Note key findings or conclusions
5. Begin to discuss strategies for improvement
5. Begin to discuss strategies for improvement
6. Be prepared to share your findings with the large group
